page.title: 04A WALK THROUGH DEFYNNOG
page.content: If you cross the road to Merthyr by the old Defynnog School (now a pine restoration craftshop) you come to an old narrow lane. The houses are small and close together, just like in the olden days. At the end of this lane, by the disused chapel, is the village stand pipe; now it is used to water the gardens. Another relic is a horse mount and ring set in the wall of one of the nearby cottages. When you go down the next lane you walk on cobble stones until you get to the delapidated mill. The mill used to grind flour for the whole area, it hasn't been used for years but you can still see where the river's course was altered to drive the wheel. Right after the old mill is the main road. If you cross by the Tanners Arms you can walk to the Parish Church. (Hazel Jones) (See photo 2)
